title: Housing credit moves back into growth
text:
‘‘There are some early anecdotal signs that lenders are easing off on the scrutiny being applied to borrower balance sheets. The positive outcome for Westpac over ASIC has probably helped to alleviate some of the focus on discretionary spending, with lenders likely to focus more on non-discretionary spending behaviour that would be difficult to change once being approved for a loan.’’

Importantly, he says, the outcome of Westpac v ASIC affirms that pre-loan spending behaviours aren’t necessarily reflected in behaviour post-loan.

“Borrowers can modify their expenses for discretionary spending such as luxury items, dining out or entertainment, but non-discretionary spends such as utility bills and other debt repayments are much harder to reduce.”

In other words: caviar and cabernet and the cleaner are on the chopping block, but power, water and solid Wi-Fi are non-negotiable.

And increased competition will be at the centre of the coming recovery, he says.

Hard bargain

“I can’t remember a time when the mortgage market has been more competitive than it is at the moment,” Lawless says.

“The banking sector is losing market share to non-banks – and digital banks are emerging as another source of lending. For ‘high quality’ borrowers (borrowers with a larger deposit and high income relative to their debt) this means they can drive a hard bargain and secure extremely low mortgage rates.

“Borrowers who are less credit worthy (smaller deposits and a higher ratio of debt relative to income) may not be able to secure the best loan terms despite such stiff competition amongst lenders.”

Advertisement

And mortgage brokers will help – albeit in a complex landscape.

“The mortgage environment is arguably more complex than it has ever been with such a broad range of products, differential interest rates and add-ons,” he says.

“Mortgage brokers are playing an increasingly important role in helping consumers navigate this complexity to choose the most appropriate lender and product based on the borrower’s individual needs and the quality of their application.”

According to research from Comparator, mortgage brokers were involved with 56 per cent of all loans originated over the June quarter, which was a record for any June quarter share of market.

“The result highlights that consumers are relying on the services of mortgage brokers more than they ever have in the past.”

Aussie Home Loans chairman John Symond. John Veage

Aussie supremo John Symond agrees: “Today’s property market has all the right conditions: it’s steady, we’ve got low interest rates and national average auction clearance rates are above 75 per cent.”

And what does the future hold?

Lawless says: “Lenders are rebuilding trust following the royal commission and they are doubling down on their service offering.

“Mortgage brokers have demonstrated their value by offering a service that cuts through the complexity of the market via a strong service offering that appeals to consumers.

“No doubt lenders will be keen to match the broker service offering, and we can already see this from mobile lenders who can travel to meet prospective borrowers and work to more flexible hours.”
description: Property market begins to recover as record low interest rates and easier home loan serviceability assessments combined with increasing competition among lenders begin to take effect.
